entry.title: [humankind] History's Biggest Fraud. Part 4 [thinkagain] Strong arguments don't always persuade everyone
entry.content:
History’s biggest fraud

First theory: The process of domestication of animals may have begin with selective hunting.

Second theory: When hunters caught and adopted a little lamb, fattening it for some weeks or months when there was plenty of food and they killed and ate it.

Domesticatated animals also spread around the world with people.

10 000 years there are not more than a few million sheep, a few million cattle, goats, pigs and chicken and that they are mostly restricted to to certain area in Afro-Asia.

Today in contrast, the world contains about 1 billion sheep, 1 billion pigs, 1.5 cattle, 25 billion chickens. So for a narrow evolutionaty perspective, which measures the success of a species by the number of DNA copies the agrocultural revolution was a wonderful success for checkens and cattle, pigs, sheep and goats.

Farmers in certain societies in New Guinea, what they did is to slice off, to cut a part of the nose of the pig. And this causes the pig a severe pain whenever he tries to sniff around.

Cows, goats and sheep produce milk only after they give birth to caives and kids and lambs. And only as long as these youngsters are suckling because the milk of cows, it is meant to feed the children of the cow. In order to ensure continues supply of animal milk, a farmer need all the time to have cows and kids and little lambs for suckling.

Agrocultural revolution was a huge success from the point of evolutionary proccess, but it was catastrophe for cows, chickens and pigs as individuals.

Strong arguments don’t always persuade everyone

Religious and cultural beliefs can be too hard to overcome. So even the best arguments can have disbelievers. Human beings aren’t always logical and don’t always believe scientifically proven cause and effect.

A valid, strong and sound argument in and of itself may never persuade or convert anyone to adpt a different way of thinking. So what. What a strong argument does is to communicate clearly what one think and why they think it.

Don’t set your sights too high. If your goal is to persuade everybody, you’re going to be constantly frustrated.

What else Arguments used for? Explanation

You can use Arguments in order to explain things. Explaining is gigivng a reason why something happened (or why it is true).

When you justify something, your audience might not believe what you are justifying.

When you explain something, you and your audience both believe what you are explaining.

The goal of explanation is to help people understan why something is true.

Kinds of Explanations:

  • Causal: Why did the bridge collapse? The earthquake shook it.
  • Teleological (purpose): Why did Joe go to the grocery store? To buy milk.
  • Formal: Why doesn’t this peg fit in that round hole? The peg is square.
  • Material: Why is this golf club light? It is made of graphite.

entry.title: [humankind] History's Biggest Fraud. Part 2 and 3 [thinkagain] What are Arguments used for?
entry.content:
In this part we’re going to talk about the question why people move towards wheat? It’s not offer people economic security, not good for the diet, because has less mineral and vitamins, hard to digest and bad for our teeth. The life of a peasant is usually less secure than the life of a hunter gatherer, they gather, hunt and eat a lot of of different food.

Chance of the men to die at the hand of another man was 25% in ancient agricultural village say 8 000 years ago. Today in the world it’s about 1.5% - 1%, even less.

Cultivating wheat provided much more food per unit of territory for a given field. Homo sapiens could get much more food if we used agriculture than if we hunted and gather what frows naturally in that field. Extra food enable the number of Sapiens to grow exponentially.

Evolutionary success of a specie is measured only by the number of copies of DNA in existence. Because of extra food, villages and connection to the one place woman could have a child every year instead of having baby just every three or four years as was the case with hunter gatherers (woman were very careful to wait until the previous child could walk before having another baby).

Moreover, infectious diseases began to spread rapidly (from domesticated animals to people, problems with toilet and garbage piles, diet was worse and immune system was less robust)

Population kept growing and growing all the time, and therefore, even if people wanted to go back from agruculture back to the hunting and gathering, they can’t because they have much more people to feed. So they kept watering the wheat firlds and feeding all “extra” people.

The disire to have a better and easier life actually treapped human kind in harder living conditions.

Luxuries tend to become necessities. Once people get used to a certain habit, they begin to count on it and to take it for granted and eventually they reach the position when they can’t live without it.

Example with email vs post mail. It obviously very good and easy to be able to send something and get response very fast versus sending the message with envelope and stamps on it and get the answer in weeks or even month. The life of people who use emails is not more easy and more relaxed than the life of people who used only letters. Humanity search for an easier life, releases immense forces of change which tranform the world in ways that nobody envisioned or wanted. It’s extremely difficult to foresee all the results of our actions and all the factors which in order to make really good decisions, we need to tak into account.

Alternative explanation about agricultural revolution. It suggests that what brought about the agricultural revolution was not the search for an easier and more comfortable life, rather, it was the attempt to fulfil some kind of cultural or religious aspiration.

What are Arguments used for?

Persuading is making people believe or do something that they would not otherwise believe or do.

Justifying is showing someone a reason to believe the conclusion.

Justification tries to give good reasons. Persuasion tries to change your belief or actions (and bad reasons can do that).

When someone give you an argument, you need to ask a series of questions:

  1. Is the arguer trying to change someone’s mind? If so, the purpose is persuasion.

  2. Is the arguer trying to give some kind of reason to believe something? If so, the purpose is justification.

entry.title: [humankind] The Human Flood. Part 2 and History's Biggest Fraud. Part 1 [modernart] Paintings, Part 1. [thinkagain] Why Arguments Matter
entry.content:
Ecological disaster. In part two we’re talking about America. Part I was about ecological disaster in Australia. They come to American from Sibiria to Alaska without significant genetic mutation and evolution.

History’s Biggest Fraud

If things were so good at the time of the hunter gatherers, why did the agricultural revolution happen?

For the first 2.5 millin years of their existence, human managed very well without agriculture. They fed themselves by gathering plant and by hunting animals that lived and bread without much human intervention.

About 12 000 years ago sapiens began to devote almost all their time and effort to manipulate the lives of a few animal and plant species. Like wheat or potatoes or chicken or cows, from sunrise to sunset, sewed seeds and watered plants, and plucked weeds from the ground and led sheep to pasture.

That leads to the agricultural revolution, transition from a life of hunting and gathering to a life of controlling and cultivation plants and animals ofccured for the first time around 9000 BC in southeastern Turkey, western Iran and Levant (scholars once believed that agriculture began only this area in the Middle East and from there spread all around the world, but this theory is no longer accepted. Today scholars agree, that agriculture sprang up in several different parts of the world independently).

Agricultural revoltion was a great leap forward for human kind. It’s wrong to think that the agricultural revoltion began because people became smarter and discovered things about animals and plants that they didn’t know before.

Compared with lives of most peasants, the ancient hunter gatherers enjoyed a better life, they enjoyed a healthier diet, they worked fewer hours and they spent their time doing much more interesting things than the peasants. Also they were less in danger of starvation, of disease and probably even less in danger of human violence.

The average peasant in the small village, he or she worked harder than the average forager thousands of years prevously. And they got in return a worse diet. The agricultural revolution from this prospective turns out to be the biggest fraud in history.

Meat covers almost 2.25 million square km of the globe’s surface. How did it turn wheat from being insignificant to be ubiquitous, everywhere? Wheat did it by manipulating homo sapiens!

The human body is not adapted to all this back breaking toil, to all this clearing rocks and weeding of fields and carrying water buckets from the river. Human body paid for all this effort with a very high price.

Also, people were forced to settle permanently next to the wheat field and this completely changed their way of life. From nomadic foragers, human turned into peasants living in a village in one place. Wheat domisticated us

Paintings. We’re starting off with Eugene Delacroix was born just after the French Revolution in 1798 and he lives on to 1863.

Art should lead to heightened emotion within a bourgeois sphere, middle class sphere.

ThinkAgain

Professor name is Walter Sinnott-Armstrong from Duke University. He going to teach me how to reason and argue. Think more deeply. We going approach reason by arguments, because arguments are just ways to express reasons. And if you can understand arguments, you can understand reason.

Good Arguments => Good Reason for the ways which you think and behave.

Understand arguments helps to avoid mistakes.

  1. How to analyze arguments (which passages includes arguments)
  2. How to evaluate deductive arguments (propositional and categorical logic)
  3. How to evaluate inductive arguments (generalization, application, inference to the best explanation, causal reasoning, decision making)
  4. How to avoid fallacies (vagueness неопределенность, ambiguity, irrelevance, begging the question)

You can’t win an argument just by yelling at someone. That doesn’t make the argument any better because that’s not the point of arguing.

You can’t win an argument simply by calling your opponent a stupid git.

Complainings just expressing your emotion about the situation.

An argument is a connected series of statements to establish a definite proposition. Sometimes arguments are intended to stablish a propostion, but in other cases they’re intended to help us understand the proposition and the reasons why the proposition is true.

Argument:

  1. a series of sentences, statements, or propositions
  2. where some are the premises
  3. and one is the conclusion
  4. where the premises are intended to give a reason for the conclusion.

Morality becomes a kind of self-torture.

But have you ever asked yourselves sufficiently how much the erection of every ideal on earth has cost? … We modern men are the heirs of the conscience-vivisection and self-torture of millenia…

When I kill myself, given that I’m doing it for my own benefit, I’ve obviously got my own agreement. I can’t kill myself agains my will. That seems pretty important. Consent can make it acceptable to do to someone what would normally be wrong in the absence of their consent.

Boxing is moraly acceptable. But I can’t hit someone without concent. Consent makes it legitimate to harm people.

Suicide isn’t always legitimate, but it’s sometimes legitimate.

Face death without fear and without illusion.

Deciding under Uncertainty

At what point would it be true that suicide might be rational?

Burn with great deal of pain while their skin regragrafted and the life. And early on in that period, this person said, although he believed that he’d eventually recover, what he was going to have to go through was so horrible that he wished he were dead.

Case of Illness

Since you never know for sure that you won’t recover, since there’s always a possibility pf recovery, suicide never makes sense. After all, we all know that there’s constant progress in medicine, people are always making breakthroughs and what seems like an incurable disease one day may have some sort of cure the next. But if you killed youself, you’ve thrown away any chance of getting that cure. But it seems wrong!

Morality of Suicide. Theological theory restrict suicide, it’s God’s will.

Struggle to Intensity

Every art, every philosophy may be viewed as an aid and remedy in the service of growing and striving life: they always presuppose suffering and sufferers. On the Genealogy of Morals (1887)

Judge philosophy how it help to be more alive. Suffering is part of the proccess of invigoration (укрепления).

Ressentiment - is shows us what you can call a dynamic of reversal. Once upon of time in ancient days there was no moral distinction between good and evel. There was just distinction between good and bad. What makes me feel weak is evel and suddenly the weak person says, all those strong people, those blond beasts, the popular kids, the folks who seem to have it all, those are evil. Why? Because they have it all and I don’t have it. They’re evel, because they have what it takes to be successfull to dominate others.

To demand that strength does not express itself as strength, that it must not consist of a will to overpower, a will to throw down, a will to rule, a thirst for enemies and opposition and triump - that is as unreasonable as to demand that weakness express itself as strength.

If forgetfulness (забывчивость) were not present, there could be no happiness, no cheerfulness, no hoping, no pride, no present. The man in whom this repression apparatus is harmed and not working properly we can compare to a dyspeptic ( and not just compare ) - he is ‘finished’ with nothing. On the Genealogy of Morals

Panishment makes the human animal rememer these values. Suffering goes together with morality, because when we have moral values, we want to see those who violate those values suffer. And suffering, he thinks, is the underbelly of morality.

To see others suffer does one good, to make others suffer even more: this is a hard saying, but an acient, mighty, human, all-too-human principle to which even the apes might subscribe… Without cruelty there is no festival…

entry.content:
Intensity replaces morality. Baudelaire and Nietzsche whose work becomes very important for post-modernism much later, they reject the hierarchies that had governed ethics, politics and aesthetics. And in so doing, developed a framework for making poetry and philosophy, respectively. Shoot the clock and let’s see the world without an expectation that you have to be somewhere else soon.

French revolution 1848. 1853 to 1870 Paris became a new kind of place. New kinds of lighs, which illuminate the boulevard. New kinds of people you see all the time. That becomes the material for Baudelaire poetry.

Two terms to keep in mind - flaneur and dandy. Dandy - a man unduly devoted to style, neatness, and fashion in dress and appearance. Public presentation of difference, of exaggerated willingness, even desire to be seen. The dandy wants to be seen.

Bohemians are the ones who are living in a garret, living the life on the margins. They’re not just poor, they’re living in poverty, because they think poverty is an escape from bourgeois convention. And Baudelaire as a poet vacillates between the dandy and the Bohemian.

Bohemian - a person, as an artist or writer, who lives and acts free of regard for conventional rules and practices.

They both anti-conventinal.

Flaneurs - strolls around without purpose, moving through the city streets without going to a particular place. They’re open to possibility. You don’t know what youre going to run into. Most of us living in situations where we constrict the possibility in favor of security or convention. You see the people you want to see, segregation insures that in many places in this country and abroad, segregation by class, by race, by gender sometimes.

Anythin that you can do to pursue intensity might lead actually to real poetry or real art.

The Rationality of Suicide

We face the possibility to end our life earlier than it would end otherwise. Two-state requirements not met, because death is not the state. You can make assumption based on before and after, because it is no after at all. But in the same case with two-state requirements we can’t say it’s better to be alive then.

entry.title: Workout
entry.content:
workout

to buy

  • belt (olympic 2” or ppowerlifting belt 4” )
  • wraps. wrist wraps (24”)

  • one day will be devoted to the standing military press, one day to the parallel squat, one day to the deadlift and one day to the bench press.

  • each training cycle lasts 4-6 weeks. This depends on how many days a week you train.

  • the first week you will do 3 sets of 5 reps (3x5)

  • the second week you will do 3 sets of 3 reps (3x3)
  • the third week you will do 1 set of 5 reps, 1 set of 3 reps and 1 set of 1 rep (5/3/1)
  • after the fourth week, you begin again with 3 sets of 5 reps.
  • each week and each set has a percentage to follow, so you won’t be guessing what to do.

Day 1

Warm-up Standing Military Press Assistance Exercises

Day 2

Warm-up Deadlift Assistance Exercises

Day 3

Warm-up Bench Press Assistance Exercises

Day 4

Warm-up Squat Assistance Exercises

First, know your maxes for the four lifts

  • squat
  • bench
  • deadlift
  • standing military press

How? Take 80%-85% of your supposed max and perfom as many reps ass possible. Then plug the reps and the weight into this formula to get your estimated 1RM:

Weight * Reps * 0.0333 + Weight = Estimated 1RM

Take 90% of this number and use this as your ”max” for the first 4 weeks of the training cycle. For example, let’s say I have a 300 deadlift, 220 squat, 180 bench press and 100 military press, then my numbers would look like this:

Deadlift: 300 * 0.9 = 270 Squat: 220 * 0.9 = 198 Bench: 180 * 0.9 = 162 Military press: 100 * 0.9 = 90

Week 1

65% * 5 reps, 75% * 5 reps, 85% * 5 or more reps

Week 2

70% * 3 reps, 80% * 3 reps, 90% * 3 or more reps

Week 3

75% * 5 reps, 85% * 3 reps, 95% * 1 or more reps

Week 4

40% * 5 reps, 50% * 5 reps, 65% * 5

Warming up

1 * 5 40% 1 * 5 50% 1 * 3 60% Worksets

When you get sick, go on vacation, etc what to do?

  • start where you left off and only get prescribed reps.
  • do the deload week first to get back into the swing of things

What to do if you miss a training day?

  • just pick up where you left off.

entry.title: [modernart] Re-imagining the World. [humankind] The Cognitive Revolution 5. [death] How to live given the certainty of Death
entry.content:
Darwin understands the variations are transmitted and controlled through the breeding process and he understands that in nature something like that process takes place too.

The human race is not the goal of evolution, it is one of the products of evolution. The tree of evolution, Darwin says, and is without a trunk.

How fleeting are the wishes and effors of man! How short his time! and consequently how poor will his products be, compared with those accumulated by nature during whole geological periods. Can we wonder, then, that nature’s productions should be far ‘truer’ in character than man’s productions; that they should be infinitely better adapted to the most complex conditions of life, and should plainly bear the stamp of far higher workmanship? On the Origin of Species

Biogeography Paleontology - geologic periods Embryology - embryonic development Morphology - studies the form and structure of something without consideration of the function.

In short, we shall have to treat species in the same manner as those naturalists treat genera, who admit that genera are merely artificial combinations made for convenience. This may not be a cheering prospect; but we shall at least be freed from the vain search for the undiscovered and undiscoverable essence of the term species.

Darwinian selection theory is a two-step process - the production of variation unrelated to the adaptive requirements of the organism, and differential perpetuation of those variations that serve adaptive needs.

Intelligence is in a adaprive byproduct of evolution. Intelligence was on of those variations that get perpetuated because it helped in the struggle to survive. Morality is an adaptive change through the advantages of living together. Sexual selection depends not on the struggle for existence, but on the struggle between males for the possession of the females.

I fully admin that it is atonishing that the females of many birds and some mammals should be endowed with sufficient taste to appreciate ornaments, which we have reason to attribute to sexual selection; and this is even more astonishing in the case of reptiles, fish and insects. The Descent of Man

We thus learn that man is descended from a hairy, tailed quadruped, probably arboreal in its habits, and an inhabitant of the Old World. The Descent Of Man

The truth is a compliment you give to the ideas you like. DeGrody

Homo sapience is able to change it’s social, economic, and political behavior very rapidly. Bonobo (dominated by females) and Common Chimpanze (dominated by Alpha Male).

Three teories what happened with Cognitive Revolution starts 70 000 years ago:

  1. About people being able to share more information about the outside world. About lions, rivers, plan and carry out all kinds of complex actions such as avoiding lion or hunting bison.

  2. Gossip. Transfer a lot of information not about lions, but about sapiense and the social relationship between Sapiens. It enable Sapiense to live in larger and more cohesive groups up to about 150 individuals.

  3. Fiction and fiction language. Ability to transmit large quantites of information about things that don’t really exist at all, like tribal spirits and ghosts. Opens the way for cooperation between very large numbers of strangers. Also it opened the way to the rapid innovation of social behavior.

Evolutionaty Psychology

Eating habit. Obisity results from the conditions under which our ancestors lived 30 or 40 or 50 thousands years ago and their complecated interaction between those conditions and the situation today. 50000 years ago if a woman was walking along the savanna, and suddenly seeing a tree full of ripened fruit, the most sensible thing to do back then was to eat as many of these fruits as quickly as possible for two reasons. First of all sweet things, things with a lot of sugar in them were very rare in the savannah 50 000 years ago and the second reason is because somebody else will eat it, so better to it as many of them as possible.

My DNA and psychological urges tell me the same way as my grate parents 50 000 years reacted in the savannah.

Women could have relation with several man and same for man. And no concept marriage for life. Commune raised the childrens.

Collective fatherhood - child could have more than one father.

How should we live? We could do it wrong. Mortality rubs our chance do-over.

We have to be careful in our aims and we have to be careful in our execution of our aims, because we have a rather limited amount of time to do it over.

We just don’t have enought time to flail around, try a little of this, try a little of that. And so what death forces us to do is to be careful. The face about our death requires paying attention.

Ok, I’m paying attention, so what should I do with my life? What should I fill it with? What kinds of contents should we try to fill our lives with?

Strategy number one says given that you’ve only got a finite amount of time, pack as much as you can into life. Given the dangers of failure if you aim too ambitiously, you should settle for the kinds of goals that you’ve virtually guaranteed that you’ll accomplish. The pleasure of food, company, sex, ice cream. Eat, drink, and be merry, for tomorrow we die.

Strategy number two says that’s all well and good, you’ve got a pretty high chance of succeeding at that. The trouble with strategy number one is the goods that you can achive are small. You might want to write a novel, compose a symphony or marry and raise a family.

Grant me but one good summer, you Powerful Ones! And but one autumn, ripening for my song,

  So that my heart, fulfilled by sweet play, 
     Might the more willingly die, contented.

The soul deprived in life of its godly right Won’t rest in Orcus, either, not down below,

  Yet if the sacred boon my heart craves 
     Should in the future succeed—the poem—

Welcome, then, silence, hail to the world of shades! I’ll rest content, even if my lyre and play

  Did not conduct me down there; once I
     Lived as the gods live, and more we don’t need.

I’m just deluding myself as well, when I think there’s something grander, something signigicant, something valuable about having made an accomplishment, having achieved something that continues beyond me.

We live and then we’re dead is to try to make the life that you’ve got as good as possible, as valuable as possible, to pack as much into it as you can.

Life is Suffering - if life isn’t worth having overall, then its loss is not a bad thing, but a good thing. The trick isn’t to make life as valuable as it could be, but rather to come to recognize that on balance, life isn’t positive, but negative.

Buddhist believe if you think hard about the underlying nature of life, you’ll see that everyplace there is loss. Life is suffering.

entry.content:
The legend of Peugeot company What is it? Maybe you can say it is cars that Peugeot manufactories, but it seems wrong because Peugeot company is not the same as the Peugeot cars. Maybe you can say it is factories and showrooms, but it is not. So perhaps Peugeot is the people who work in the factories and in the offices? It’s clearly not true. Peugeot is a story, it is a fiction, something that we invented, it belongs to a particular kind of fictions which is called limited liability companies.

Hoc est corpus meum. (this is my body)

How to convince millions of people, strangers to one another to believe the same stories about gods or about limited liability companies or about nations or about human rights? It helps sapiens to manage millions of strangers to cooperate towards common goals.

Imagined reality is something that everybody believes in and as long as this common belief persists, the imagined reality is a real force in the world.

Dual reality - on the on hand there is the objective reality of revirs and trees and lions, on the other hand there is the imagined reality of gods and nations and corporations. As time went by, the imagined reality became more and more powerful, so that today the very survival of rivers and trees and lions depends on the grace of imagined entities such as goods and nations and corporations.

Charles Darwin

It’s difficult to believe in the dreadful but quiet war lurking just below the serene facade of nature. Charles Darwin, 1839

Utilitarianism it’s the greatest happiness of the greatest number that is the measure of right and wrong…

Romanticism versus Utalitarianism. For romantics we make the world as we live in it.

Joshua Mill said that romanticism saved him. Joshua Mill was a prodigy child, he learned Greek by the age of three, high level mathematics by four or five, various languages and then he had a nervous breakdown, he has crisis.

You can do what you want as long as it doesn’t hurt someone else. This notion of liberty is key for modern political thought

Suppose that all your objects in life were realized… would this be a joy and happiness to you? And an irrepressible self-consciousness distinctly answered “No!” At this my heart sank within me; the whole foundation on which my life was constructed fell down. John Stuart Mill, Autobiography

And then he read about melancholy and dejection, and he says, these people know about life. They don’t say oh, you should flip a coin or go and take a class. entry.content:
Lucretious says, look, most of us are upset and anxious at the fact that we’re going to die. We think death is bad for us. There’ll be this period after my death in which I won’t exist. And deprivation account helps us to say why it’s bad, because during this period of nonexistence, you’re not enjoying the good things in life. But wait a minute, the period after you die isn’t the only period during which you don’t exist. It’s not the only period in which if only you were still alive, you could still be enjoying the good things in life. There’s another period of nonexistence. It’s the period before my birth

It is bad? Lucretius says that’s silly, nobody upset about the fact that there was an eternity before they were born.

Before born you don’t life, but with death you lost it. So, we can say, that we care about that part after death more than the one before birth. Because the one after death involves loss, and the one before birth does not.

We imaging to living the longer life. But what is it that happens when I say, if only I’d been born earlier? Well, says Feldman, you don’t actually imagine a longer life, you just shift the entire life and start it earlier. When we imaging being born earlier we don’t imaging having longer life. Nothing better about having a life earlier, according to the deprivation account.

So, Feldman says, no wonder, no surprise that you care about the nonexistence after death. Because when you imagine that being different, you imagine a longer life. But when you start thinking about the nonexistence before birth and you imagine that being different, you don’t imagine more goods in life, you just imagine them taking place at a different time.

Derek Parfit says, it’s true that when I think about the nonexistence after I die that’s loss, whereas the nonexistence before I’m born, that’s not loss, that’s mere “schmoss”. And it’s true that we need an explanation about why loss is worse than “schmoss”. But we can see that this is not an arbitrary preference on our part, because in fact, it’s part of a quite general pattern we have of caring about the future in a way that we don’t care about the past. This is a very deep fact about human caring. We are oriented towards the future and concerned about what happens in it, in a way that we’re not oriented and concerned about what happened in the past.

Parfit’e got a very nice example, imagine that you’ve got some condition, some sort of medical condition that will kill you unless you have an operation. So fair enought, you’re going to have the operation. This will allow you to live your life. Unfortunately in order to perfom the operation, they can’t have you anesthetized. You have to be awayke, perhaps in order to tell the surgeon “Yeah, that’s where it hurts,” and it’s a very painful operation. Only one thing we can do is this: give a super local medication and you will not remember anything about the operation itself (24 hours completely wiped out). So you’re in the hospital and you wake up and you ask yourself, “Huh, have I had the operation yet or not?” Don’t know, right? So you ask the nurse, “Have I had the operation yet or not?” She says “I don’t know, we have a couple on the hall today who are some of whom have had it and some of whom are scheduled to have it later today. Let me go look at your file, I’ll come back and I’ll tell you.” I want it to be the case that I’m one of the people who’s already had the operation. I don’t want to be one of the people who hasn’t yet had the operation. We want the pain to be in the past. We care more about what’s happening in the futer than we care about what’s happening in the past.
